page.title: 10ASHURST BRIDGE SEWAGE WORKS
page.content: Ashurst Bridge sewage treatment works was opened in 1936. It is an automatic plant and no men work there but it is checked daily for approximately four hours. Its purpose is to treat domestic and industrial waste. Eleven hundred cubic metres of waste goes through the works every day. The waste is pumped into the reception chamber where the heavy grit and silts are separated. These go into a detritor chamber, then to the primary settlement tanks. The solids are then separated from the sewage and sludge which is pumped into the sludge storage tanks and disposed of to land or sea. Then the solids pass through filter beds and are pumped to the final settling tanks. From there it is pumped into some kind of waterway, in this case the Bartley Water.
